text: The ironic thing is that the author points out NumFocus as evidence that Python's data ecosystem is well funded, whereas not only is the Julia project funded by NumFocus, but JuMP and SciML are as well.

attachments.title: Is Julia a Misuse of Free Software in the Name of Open Source?  | Hacker Noon
attachments.text: For the past few days I have been spectating an interesting conversation in the Julia community. Reading the comments of VIP members of the Julia Community has been my motivation in writing this text. I will start with a summary of Julia's history from Wikipedia:

text:
> According to their survey, 37% Have Created, Developed or Contributed to an Open Source Package in the Julia General Registry. This very small amount indicates that the Julia community is not very familiar with the culture of free software.
Doesn't this quote seem very odd. I think that is a lot more than python or C. Most people I know that use these languages dont ever contribute a thing to FOSS.

elements.text: According to their survey, 37% Have Created, Developed or Contributed to an Open Source Package in the Julia General Registry. This very small amount indicates that the Julia community is not very familiar with the culture of free software.
Doesn't this quote seem very odd. I think that is a lot more than python or C. Most people I know that use these languages dont ever contribute a thing to FOSS.

text: I don't have numbers for other open source projects, but I agree that just throwing a number out there without context is hardly a charitable thing to do. People can't gauge whether that's a lot of people or not - it's just a number. In the end, they'll go with what their gut tells them feels right, which can be influenced by a number of things...

text: It does seem mostly like a personal peeve, but I do have the feeling that the tone in some discourse discussions has sometimes been a bit too heated and defensive lately. To be clear, I don't mean the moderators the author cites here but that some of the responses before that could have been less dismissive of the OP and put more emphasis on explaining why things are like that while acknowledging real shortcomings IMHO. That was my impression at least, not sure how others received it.

elements.text: It does seem mostly like a personal peeve, but I do have the feeling that the tone in some discourse discussions has sometimes been a bit too heated and defensive lately. text: yeah - which is why I've partly laid off discourse in the past year or so :man-shrugging: seemed like the discussion changed from pure language stuff more towards application and usage (which is good! but not an area where I can help) and people who asked "but what about language xyz" (inadvertently) started those discussions all over again, seemingly without trying to search for previous discussions...

elements.text: yeah - which is why I've partly laid off discourse in the past year or so

text: To be honest, I'm unsure what the goal is when posting a blog-post style text on discourse - we're all acutely aware of the problems the language has, it's not like we're ignoring them, I don't think :man-shrugging:

text: Reading some of those comments, I'm wondering if my perception is highly biased. Are people finding Julia more quirky/unpredictable  than python or having trouble replacing python in production? I can't stand to go back to python, but maybe julia specifically comports with the way I think.
